item.title: Taiwan Official Discusses US Energy Cooperation at Alaska Summit
item.description: Taiwan’s top presidential aide discussed energy cooperation with US officials at a summit this week in Alaska, where a liquefied natural gas project has come into focus for potential exporting to the island.
item.dc:creator: Denise Wee, Cindy Wang

media:content.media:description: Storage sphere tanks for liquefied natural gas. Photographer: Annie Sakkab/Bloomberg

item.title: Stun Grenades, Armored Trucks in ICE Raids Spur Tensions
item.description: The Trump administration is intensifying efforts to round up migrants and it’s using increasingly aggressive tactics.
item.dc:creator: Alicia A. Caldwell

media:content.media:description: ICE agents execute a criminal search warrant at Buona Forchetta in San Diego on May 30.

item.title: Japan Won’t Wait for G-7 Summit for Possible US Trade Deal
item.description: Japan won’t necessarily wait for the Group of Seven Summit set to take place in Canada next week to seal a trade deal with the US if the two sides can agree earlier, Japan’s top negotiator Ryosei Akazawa said in Washington DC on Friday.
item.dc:creator: Akira Matsui, Yoshiaki Nohara, Sakura Murakami

media:content.media:description: Ryosei Akazawa in Washington, DC, on June 6. Photographer: Stefani Reynolds/Bloomberg

item.title: Abrego Garcia Charged With Illegally Transporting Migrants
item.description: Kilmar Abrego Garcia, the Maryland man mistakenly deported by the Trump administration to a prison in El Salvador, has been brought back to the US to face federal charges that he illegally transported undocumented immigrants within the country.
item.dc:creator: Chris Strohm, Myles Miller, Bob Van Voris

media:content.media:description: Chris Van Hollen meets with Kilmar Abrego Garcia, left, at an undisclosed location in San Salvador, El Salvador, in this handout provided by Sen. Chris Van Hollen’s Office, on April 17.

item.title: Court Rules Trump Can Exclude Journalists From Oval Office
item.description: A federal appeals court has ruled that President Donald Trump can exclude journalists from the Oval Office, Air Force One and other “restricted” spaces based on their editorial decisions, handing the administration a win in its fight with the Associated Press over access.
item.dc:creator: Zoe Tillman

media:content.media:description: Members of the media during a meeting between US President Donald Trump and Jonas Gahr Store, Norway's prime minister, not pictured, in the Oval Office of the White House in Washington, DC, US, on Thursday, April 24, 2025. Trump expressed confidence he would be able to reach an agreement on trade with Norway during a meeting with Store, but stopped short of offering to roll back his “reciprocal” tariffs without concessions.

item.title: South Korea Says Trump Agrees to Ramp Up Tariff Talks With Lee
item.description: South Korea said newly elected President Lee Jae-myung spoke for the first time with Donald Trump and agreed to seek “tangible results” in trade negotiations, after the US leader imposed a 25% tariff on all imports from its Asian ally.
item.dc:creator: Soo-Hyang Choi, Sarina Yoo

media:content.media:description: Lee Jae-myung at his inauguration in Seoul on June 4. Photographer: SeongJoon Cho/Bloomberg

item.title: Trump Pressures Fed’s Powell to Cut Rates ‘A Full Point’
item.description: President Donald Trump urged the Federal Reserve to cut interest rates by a full percentage point, intensifying his pressure campaign against Chair Jerome Powell.
item.dc:creator: Jordan Fabian, Amara Omeokwe

media:content.media:description: Jerome Powell, chairman of the US Federal Reserve, during the Federal Reserve IF 75TH Anniversary Conference in Washington, DC, US, on Monday, DC, US, on Monday, June 2, 2025. US President Donald Trump pushed Powell to lower interest rates at their first in-person meeting since the president's inauguration last week, the White House said.

item.title: Trump Says Xi to Restart Rare Earth Flows, Sets Date for Talks
item.description: President Donald Trump said his Chinese counterpart Xi Jinping had agreed to restart the flow of rare-earth materials, as negotiators from the two nations prepare to resume trade talks on June 9 in London.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer A Dlouhy, Catherine Lucey

media:content.media:description: Gantry cranes at the Port of Los Angeles.

item.title: Trump Gives Musk Silent Treatment, Will Consider Cutting Contracts
item.description: President Donald Trump said he had no plans to speak to onetime ally Elon Musk and added that he was still looking at canceling the billionaire’s government contracts — an indication that their public feud is far from over.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer A Dlouhy

media:content.media:description: Elon Musk and Donald Trump Photographer: Nathan Laine/Bloomberg, Chip Somodevilla/Getty Images

item.title: Supreme Court Leaves Intact Ban on High-Capacity Gun Magazines
item.description: The US Supreme Court turned away a fresh gun-rights appeal, refusing to question the District of Columbia’s ban on large-capacity ammunition-feeding devices.
item.dc:creator: Greg Stohr

media:content.media:description: The U.S. Supreme Court in Washington, D.C., U.S., on Monday, Oct. 4, 2021. The court's conservative wing offers a menu of opportunities to exploit its 6-3 majority, and give Republicans the type of payoff they envisioned when they pushed through Justice Amy Coney Barrett's Senate confirmation just before the 2020 election.

item.title: Supreme Court Gives DOGE Access to Social Security Data
item.description: The US Supreme Court gave the Department of Government Efficiency access to sensitive Social Security information, lifting restrictions a judge said were needed to protect the privacy of millions of Americans.
item.dc:creator: Greg Stohr, Zoe Tillman

item.title: Newsom Strikes Back at Trump After Reports of Federal Aid Cuts
item.description: California Governor Gavin Newsom shot back at the Trump administration after a report that the White House was considering cutting the state’s federal funding.
item.dc:creator: Eliyahu Kamisher, Maxwell Adler

media:content.media:description: Gavin Newsom, governor of California, during a news conference with the US Army Corps of Engineers in Altadena, California, US, on Tuesday, Feb. 11, 2025. The Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) and the US Army Corps of Engineers (USACE) will begin removing fire debris starting Tuesday from private properties damaged or destroyed by the January wildfires, officials announced Monday.

item.title: Tesla Shares Caught in the Middle of Musk-Trump Breakup
item.description: When President Donald Trump won the election in November, investors viewed Tesla Inc. as one of the biggest winners. That bet now seems to be on shaky ground after investors watched the once formidable alliance dissolve in real time.
item.dc:creator: Joel Leon

media:content.media:description: Tesla vehicles at the company's store in Colma, California.

item.title: Harvard’s Battle With Trump Reignites School Pride of Alumni
item.description: Jessica Tang has two degrees from Harvard University but barely donated directly to the school in two decades as a graduate. She’s even publicly criticized Harvard’s labor practices.
item.dc:creator: Greg Ryan

media:content.media:description: The Widener Library on the Harvard Campus in Cambridge, Massachusetts.

item.title: Xi Bets Trump Detente Leads to Future Wins on Chips, Tariffs
item.description: In the early hours of Wednesday, Donald Trump declared that Xi Jinping was “VERY TOUGH, AND EXTREMELY HARD TO MAKE A DEAL WITH!!!” Some 36 hours later, the US leader said he got what he wanted: A commitment to restore the flow of rare earth magnets.
item.dc:creator: Colum Murphy, Katia Dmitrieva, James Mayger

media:content.media:description: Xi Jinping Photographer: Kirill Kudryavtsev/Pool/AFP/Getty Images

item.title: Musk-Trump Breakup Exposes Cracks in Wall Street’s Meme Casino
item.description: It took less than a day for the great Donald Trump-Elon Musk split to reshape debates over billionaire power and influence in American capitalism.
item.dc:creator: Denitsa Tsekova, Alexandra Semenova

media:content.media:description: WASHINGTON, DC - MARCH 11: (Editor's Note: Alternative Crop) U.S. President Donald Trump, accompanied by White House Senior Advisor, Tesla and SpaceX CEO Elon Musk, walks past a Tesla Model S on the South Lawn of the White House on March 11, 2025 in Washington, DC. Trump spoke out against calls for a boycott of Elon Musk's companies and said he would purchase a Tesla vehicle in what he calls a 'show of confidence and support' for Elon Musk. (Photo by Andrew Harnik/Getty Images)

item.title: What’s Next for Trump’s Tax Bill and Musk’s Billions
item.description: This is Washington Edition, the newsletter about money, power and politics in the nation’s capital. Every Friday, White House correspondent Akayla Gardner delivers a roundup of the key news and events in politics, policy and economics that you need to know. Sign up here and follow us at @bpolitics. Email our editors here.
item.dc:creator: Akayla Gardner

item.title: Tesla’s EV Deliveries Are Seen Falling as Demand Erodes Sharply
item.description: Wall Street is reining in expectations for Tesla Inc. deliveries as the Elon Musk-run automaker struggles with waning consumer demand and the threat of reduced US federal incentives for electric vehicles.
item.dc:creator: Kara Carlson

media:content.media:description: New parked Tesla Inc. electric vehicles at a showroom in Marseille, France, on Thursday, Feb. 6, 2025. Tesla Inc. registrations plummeted 63% last month in France, the European Union’s second-biggest market for battery-electric vehicles. Photographer: Jeremy Suyker/Bloomberg

item.title: Trump Signs Order to Boost Drone Security Before World Cup
item.description: President Donald Trump signed executive orders Friday to bolster US drone capabilities, including strengthening counter-drone tools ahead of major sporting events such as the 2026 FIFA World Cup and the 2028 Summer Olympics that will be hosted in the country.
item.dc:creator: Allyson Versprille, Hadriana Lowenkron

media:content.media:description: A drone flies over a neighborhood in Houston, Texas.

item.title: Senator Calls for Closing Troubled ICE Detention Facility in New Mexico
item.description: Heinrich says conditions ‘have not improved and remain inadequate and inappropriate.’
item.dc:creator: Rachel Adams-Heard, Elena Mejia

media:content.media:description: The Torrance County Detention Facility in Estancia, New Mexico, in 2022.

item.title: Alleged Iran Money Laundering Network Hit With US Sanctions
item.description: The US imposed sanctions on a network of individuals and companies it accuses of laundering billions of dollars from illegal activities for the Iranian government, as the Trump administration continues its “maximum pressure” campaign against Tehran.
item.dc:creator: Ryan Chua

media:content.media:description: Azadi Tower in Tehran, Iran.

item.title: Tariffs, State Jabs Push Canadians to Ditch US Travel, Poll Says
item.description: Most Canadians say they plan to shun US travel this summer as the trade war between the two countries continues, according to a poll by Leger Marketing Inc.
item.dc:creator: Chaimae Chouiekh

media:content.media:description: A truck crosses the Peace Bridge at the Canada-US border in Fort Erie, Ontario, Canada, on Wednesday, April 2, 2025. US President Trump on April 2 plans to roll out tariffs on global trading partners, the centerpiece of his effort to bring back manufacturing to the US and reshape a world trade system he has long decried as unfair.

item.title: Court Fight Over Trump Ending Tariff Exemption Goes Forward
item.description: A court fight over President Donald Trump’s decision to end a US policy that exempted small-value packages from China from tariffs is moving ahead over the administration’s opposition.
item.dc:creator: Zoe Tillman

media:content.media:description: Packages at a sorting center in Beijing.

item.title: How Trump Is Going After International Students
item.description: President Donald Trump’s broad crackdown on immigration is spreading confusion and fear among the more than one million international students who attend US universities.
item.dc:creator: Erik Larson

media:content.media:description: Harvard University students wearing graduation gowns walk through Harvard Square in Cambridge, Massachusetts, US, on Thursday, May 29, 2025. US President Donald Trump said Harvard University should cap foreign student enrollment at 15%, ratcheting up his effort to force policy changes at the elite institution. Photographer: Mel Musto/Bloomberg

item.title: All About the ICC Case Against Israel’s Netanyahu
item.description: The International Criminal Court sparked an angry response from Israel in November when it issued arrest warrants for Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and the nation’s former defense minister for alleged war crimes in the Gaza Strip. The Israeli government denied the charges, saying its conduct in the conflict was in line with international law. Netanyahu’s office said the ICC’s decision was “motivated by anti-Semitic hatred of Israel.”
item.dc:creator: Sarah Jacob

media:content.media:description: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and former defense minister Yoav Gallant

item.title: EU Seeks Deeper G-7 Defense Ties to Offset Trump’s Upheaval
item.description: The European Union is racing to strengthen defense ties with key Group of Seven allies as President Donald Trump pares back the US commitment to the continent’s security.
item.dc:creator: Jorge Valero

media:content.media:description: The General Dynamics Corp. booth at the Canadian Association of Defence & Security Industries trade show in Ottawa, Ontario.

item.title: Carney to Fast-Track ‘Nation-Building’ Projects Through Bill
item.description: Prime Minister Mark Carney announced legislation on Friday to fast-track “nation-building” projects in Canada and remove internal barriers to trade in an effort to shore up the country’s economy from the US tariff barrage.
item.dc:creator: Laura Dhillon Kane

media:content.media:description: Mark Carney, Canada’s prime minister

item.title: Here Are the Many Ways Trump Is Attacking Harvard
item.description: In its campaign to pressure elite US colleges to make a wide range of policy changes, the administration of President Donald Trump has come down hardest on Harvard University.
item.dc:creator: David Voreacos

media:content.media:description: The Widener Library on the Harvard Campus in Cambridge, Massachusetts, US, on Wednesday, June 4, 2025. Harvard University won a longer-term reprieve from a Trump administration ban on enrolling international students, handing the nations oldest and richest university a victory in its battle with the White House. Photographer: Cassandra Klos/Bloomberg

item.title: ICE derrocha en envío de migrantes a remotos centros de detención
item.description: El aumento del costo del traslado de inmigrantes por parte del ICE a través del país impacta a los contribuyentes estadounidenses y perjudica las posibilidades de los detenidos de ganar sus casos judiciales.
item.dc:creator: Leon Yin, Elena Mejia, Rachel Adams-Heard, Polly Mosendz

item.title: Zelenskiy May Meet Trump on Sidelines of G-7 Summit, Aide Says
item.description: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskiy and US President Donald Trump may meet on the sidelines of this month’s Group of Seven summit in Canada, Zelenskiy’s chief of staff Andriy Yermak said on Friday.
item.dc:creator: Olesia Safronova

media:content.media:description: US President Donald Trump, left, and Volodymyr Zelenskiy, Ukraine's president, outside the West Wing of the White House in Washington, DC, US, on Friday, Feb. 28, 2025. Zelenskiy is meeting with Trump to discuss a deal that would allow the US to share in Ukraine's natural resources, hoping to start a discussion on security guarantees.
